Award.AwardTitle: US-Ireland Partnership Programme: Bridge Health Monitoring Using Cameras and Computer Vision Methods

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a US-Ireland partnership program pursuing research in structural health monitoring of bridges. The goal of this collaborative research project is to use cameras and video-image processing to identify loss of load carrying capacity of bridge structures. The camera images can be captured continuously with minimum human intervention. The image processing algorithm can be automated to assess significant change in structural health and load carrying capacity of the bridge. Conversion of camera and computer images for assessment of traffic loads and evaluation of load carrying capacity of the bridge are major research contributions of this project. Early detection of change in load carrying capacity will allow timely repair and thus extend life of the bridge. Investigators from three institutions, one each from three countries of Ireland, Northern Ireland (United Kingdom) and United States will collaborate to develop recognition of traffic loads, changes in vibration characteristics of the bridge, computer vision output, and algorithms to predict load capacity and remaining life of the bridge. The developed algorithm will be validated by observations of a bridge in Northern Ireland in the field. The project is funded by two divisions in the National Science Foundation, the Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation and International Science and Engineering.

The intellectual merit of this project will be the development of algorithms that transforms the recorded video images of a bridge into damage characteristics for the bridge structure. The structural health will be assessed within the context of structural identification with input and output characterization. This development will require new adaptations and transformations that can manage computer vision that are continuous in space for structural engineering applications. The novelties in this project are: vehicle load modeling using computer vision; bridge response using image processing; image- based structural identification using input-output signals; and framework for remaining bridge life evaluation. The development will be validated with laboratory and field experiments. The international activities among the three collaborating partners in the areas of research, education, and outreach will support the intellectual contributions and broader impact of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The civil infrastructure systems of a nation are considered vital for its national security, economic prosperity, public health and safety. Transportation infrastructure in the USA encompasses more than 4 million miles of roadway, more than 600,000 bridges, and more than 350 tunnels. The safety, serviceability and resilience of bridges of the transportation infrastructure are therefore critical. The status of bridges in the USA requires immediate attention as presented in the most recent American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE) Report Card (2017). In fact, there is an overall need for improving infrastructure as discussed by the National Academy of Engineering as one of the Grand Challenges of Engineering in the 21st century. To address the fundamental aspects of this problem, the University of Central Florida (UCF) researchers at the Civil Infrastructure Technologies for Safety and Resilience (CITRS) Laboratory focus on exploring novel algorithms and methods for accurate, practical and low-cost bridge monitoring systems that can identify and quantify any reduction in bridge safety in an objective and timely manner. 

A main research significance was the investigation of algorithms that transform the measured video images into a form that is highly damage-sensitive/change-sensitive for bridge monitoring and assessment within the context of Structural Identification with input (loading effects) and output (structure response) characterization. A new framework was proposed for structural system identification using computer vision methods. The study utilized the unique attributes of computer vision systems, where the signal is continuous in space. Therefore, new adaptations and transformations are investigated to handle computer vision data/signals for structural engineering applications.

This research significantly advanced current sensor-based structural identification with computer-vision algorithms and technologies, also leading to practical applications for damage detection of complex structures with a novel approach. The researchers investigated structural behavior and proposed improved condition indicators for damage identification, localization and quantification using practical and low-cost noncontact methods. The researchers also proposed a portable and cost-effective system for the evaluation of bridge load carrying capacity by using multiple cameras and computer vision methods. This system was verified by a series of tests on real life bridges. The proposed system along with the fundamental algorithms and the camera-based technologies can provide engineering solutions with reduced cost, time and labor. 

During the course of the NSF research project, the leading Principal Investigator (PI) and several of his students attended The National Science Foundation?s Innovation Corps (I-Corps) program. NSF I-Corps program is for developing and nurturing a national innovation network to guide scientific research toward the development of solutions to benefit society. The researchers also actively explore technology transfer benefiting the engineering practitioners and the whole society directly.

The research has contributed significant new knowledge, which could also pave the way for integrating already existing Intelligent Transportation Systems with structural health monitoring applications. While advancing the knowledge by integrating multidisciplinary concepts from theory to application (in computer vision, structural engineering, damage/change detection, structural assessment and reliability), this research has direct benefits, as aged civil infrastructure systems have become a critical societal concern from safety and economic perspectives. 

The research project has broader impact with special emphasis on STEM education and training. A number of undergraduate students were recruited as part of this program. These students were trained and mentored to excel above and beyond their academic courses. With the support of the project, three graduate students successfully received their PhD degrees. Their dissertations and publications along with the project have provided helpful insights to researchers, graduate students and civil infrastructure practitioners who are utilizing or planning to implement computer vision for civil infrastructure applications.

The engineering challenges are global. As such, the project is an international partnership program with researchers from University College Dublin (Ireland) and Queen?s University Belfast (Northern Ireland, United Kingdom). As part of this project, the partners met in different counties, organized international workshops, seminars, training, sessions in conferences and to date they still continue to collaborate. In addition to the technical exchanges, the cultural exchange of the program is significant: Including the graduate research assistants of the partners, the total number of nationalities involved in this research is nine. All the researchers have been communicating with each other in a very collegial way; they have developed life-long academic and personal friendships. 

In summary, the project has contributed to the body of knowledge extensively with the targeted intellectual objectives and merits to improve nation?s civil infrastructure; created new research and collaboration as well as educational opportunities among the international partners; provided training, advising and mentorship to post-docs, graduate and undergraduate students and; opened technology transfer opportunities. The researchers are grateful for the NSF support for this wonderful experience.
